title: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Egypt and Ethiopia before 1 January 2022?
preds: Nothing seems to happen here and since I opted for 1% months ago 0% seems to be more realistic – since one cannot choose 0,3% or so.

Talks have stalled and Ethiopia are ready for 3rd stage of Dam fill. This will irk Egypt and Sudan but unlikely to lead to conflict which would suit Ethiopia as it is mired in the Tigray war.
No change on prediction.

1) It is the dry season and thus the fight over water rights has subsided a bit until the next rainy season.
2) Ethiopia says it will move forward with the third filling, which will take all the time between now and the next rainy season, and they have not started construction yet (expected start is November).
3) Egypt recently said it hopes a diplomatic solution can be reached. "Fears that the dispute will erupt into a military conflict rose ahead of the second filling of the dam in July this year. But these fears faded after September, when Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry outlined his country’s efforts to avoid an armed conflict with Ethiopia, stressing that Egypt is committed to the negotiation process." Read more: https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2021/10/ethiopia-preps-third-filling-nile-dam-diplomacy-stalls#ixzz79qe2Gt6W ***Thus, the triggers for lethan military intervention have been pushed out beyond the date of the close of the question.
It seems the parties prefer to pursue a diplomatic and peaceful solution vs. a kinetic solution for now.

The momentum seems right now to be with diplomacy and the possibility of resumed talks. A lethal confrontation in itself would be a big and rare event, and I think we would most likely see indications of heated up language before such an event. So, right now I'm sticking at 1% but very open to revising that ahead.
I don't see any material changes in the situation that affect my forecast.

Significantly reduced my forecast for a couple of key reasons. The primary reason is what appears to be a significant toning down of rhetoric from Eygpt (and Sudan) - as indicated in my previous forecast, Egypt appears to benefit from using diplomatic and legal leverage. A recent statement from the UN Security Council (https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/2021/09/16/egypt-says-un-statement-on-nile-dam-forces-ethiopia-to-be-seriously-involved/) clearly supports Egypt's position so Egyptian aggressive would be counter-productive to their interests. Egypt is taking alternative steps to boost other hydroelectric options (https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2021/09/egypt-overhaul-hydropower-plants-amid-nile-dam-crisis) suggesting an adaptation. Ethiopia is distracted but its conflict in the Tigray region, and armed conflict between the two nations overall now seems much less likely (https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2021/08/takeaway-egypt-weighs-options-nile-dam-ethiopia-escalates-war-tigray).

Ethiopia currently involved in Civil War.  Egypt assisting (monetarily for example) in exchange for Dam agreement seems most likely.  Bombing it a second option, but probably not a military conflict.
Egypt has previously brought these problems to the UN for resolution and doesn't seem like there's need for military forces at this point.
[Economist reading]

Egypt may have a 10,000,000,000 budget but they would loose a large percent of their equipment just getting to Ethiopia.  Egypt might not pay their troops properly and they might revolt.  Ethiopians are a warrior race, Egypt's win is not a sure thing.  I think that Sisi is talking nothing more.

Some interesting thoughts here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1316757 However, in the scheme of tensions between countries over contentious matters, lethal confrontations remain rare (as a baseline).
Not seeing anything that would lead me to believe that a confrontation will occur before stated time. Tweaking forecast down.

Likely not. Just no border to fight over and there isn't much of a history of Egyptian troops being active in Sudan that I can tell. The Egyptian military could, potentially, order some kind of airstrikes, but that seems very much out of character for Egypt to do that and the ability to project power so far away might be difficult.
There may be sabotage which results in fatalities but it might not be traced to the military until well after the fact.

Context:
The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) is not only the key to Ethiopia’s future development and prosperity but also African states close to the river Nile.
GERD is an hydroelectric dam which will provide electricity for Ethiopian domestic use and will be exported to other African states bring impetus the continent’s development. The problem: 
Ethiopia wants to continue filling the dam without assuring downstream riparian states Sudan and Egypt that during this filling period their supplies of water will not be affected and a binding dispute resolution mechanism agreement is put in place. Attempts at mediation by the AU, US and EU have thus far failed. China has investments interest both protagonists (Egypt and Ethiopia) but has so far, publicly, remained silent. A military confrontation is a loose –loose situation for all stakeholders and could destabilise the MENA region and arrest Africa’s development. Sudan’s position is weak because it has a transitional government. Ethiopia is emerging from the Tigray conflict weakened (some suggest that Egypt fomented the Tigray conflict deliberately to that end). Resolution:
Diplomacy via the front and back doors must encourage the cooler heads to prevail – will that happen?
The alternative will be disastrous for all concerned especially Africa as a continent.  0.9% chance of any form of lethal confrontation.
Based on the location alone, a military operation by Egypt would be complex and risky to pull off.
seems unlikely given the time frame
Egypt can still apply pressure thru Proxies inside the country,
Egypt acts with greater restraint as Ethiopia CAN turn the Nile off now.
Lethal conflict still poses a greater risk to regional stability than the completion of the dam. It will be avoided if possible.
not zero but if the weather heats up yes

I don't believe it will happen in such a short time frame. The dispute is serious, and it's unclear how appeals to the UN will help. I think a hot conflict of some sort is always possible given the fundamentals of the area and the impact to the river, and it would only take a spark from a small aggressive group ('non-governmental') to start, escalating to 'official' government forces from there. But the question is whether this happens by the end of the year. I think over the next 2-3 years, the chance rises, unless large concessions are made in some fashion.

Egypt keep strong relation with Dam's financers.
Also The Egyptian president is always stressing on peaceful action so as long as he is ruling Egypt ( no evidence of Entropy to coup or some thing like), no chance.
No clear spark that would result in a confrontation
Unlikely at this point. The Renaissance Dam could lead to an armed conflict or proxy war but not by the deadline of this question.
Rising tensions and possibly use of the conflict to play into nationalistic politics is the only reason there is a small chance of bloodshed.
I am expecting lethal skirmishes in several countries, over the next few years. Believe the tensions about race and civil liberty will become even bigger in the West than the dam in the Ethiopia.

I don't believe a lethal conflict is likely given that both nations and their stability are of strategic interest to not only the United States but other foreign powers as well. This will likely result in some sort of arbitration whether it is with the U.S, U.N., or other powers. Additionally, the lack of appetite for an armed conflict by both should keep this conflict in the cold.

Good Rain is forecast this year so if Ethieopia keeps the water flowing their is less probability of conflict https://reliefweb.int/report/ethiopia/wetter-usual-season-expected-over-northern-part-region

The chance of a military conflict seems low at this point with additional mediations and negotiations ahead. A likely military scenario, if one did occur, is Egypt bombing the dam and attempting to avoid casualties.
Ethiopia overwhelmingly preoccupied with domestic conflict. However, one must leave a margin for accidents.

Currently seems unlikely overall. The tension over the Dam is philosophical and rhetorical so far, and from what I have read the downstream countries of Egypt and the Sudan are seeking legally-binding assurances and appealing through the African Union and UN Security Council (albeit without much success at the moment). Upstream, Uganda is sympathetic to the plight and Ethiopia does not appear to have much backing - therefore Egypt (and probably the Sudan) would need to be the aggressors and this would likely detract from the political support they need longer-term. The incentives don't seem to align. Furthermore, I'm not aware of any recent skirmishes or military tensions that could flare up or get out of hand. Finally, the actual on-the-ground consequences are likely to be longer-term so lack an acute trigger that could drive military action. Against this, I understand that there are domestic pressures in both Egypt and Ethiopia that could 'benefit' both governments in unifying their populations. Escalating the threat of military conflict could therefore help domestic politics and also energise external parties to overcome their reluctance and mediate. I therefore see a small risk that such posturing results in a skirmish with at least one fatality, or alternatively that a military intervention to disrupt the dam results in inadvertent fatalities.

Very unlikely.  Egypt is still pursuing diplomatic options and talk of military action is often a matter of course in diplomacy when when nations want to emphasize importance.  Also, Egypt and Ethiopia do not share a border, which makes accidental military confrontation much lower.

Highly unlikely, but possible as the possibility of sabotage and support of militants in Ethiopia by Egypt would probably be attempted before any clash of national armies. It is much more cost efficient for state's to keep lethal violence at one degree of distance for the time being.

At the moment (mid-July), the overall risk appears to be minimal. Everyone involved wants a diplomatic solution. Nevertheless: The Egyptian military and the Sudanese military are doing joint exercises. There is also a border conflict between Sudan and Ethiopia (Tigray).
The situation can also change quickly if Ethiopia begins to fill the dam very quickly in the rainy season (from July).

Looking at the situation, it seems that both nations are acting diplomatically, and considering the past 10 years (since starting the dam) have gone without incident, it is unlikely that one will arise in the next 4 months. Furthermore, Egypt is a stronger nation, receiving significant foreign aid from the US. 
Despite this, there is a small chance that Ethiopia acts in such a way as to provoke Egyptian troops, but given the relative professionalism of the militaries involved, this is unlikely to result in casualties.
Unlikely but not impossible. So far, flare-ups only resulted in diplomatic tensions. Something that could disturb this trend could be the tigray conflict. In what way, I do not know.

I am going to suggest there will not be an armed conflict between Egypt and Ethiopia due to the degree of negotiations and discussions held amongst the affected parties and its elevation and interest to World players such as the US, China and Russia and the Security Council of the UN. As a point of interest and potential responsibility the site of the dam was identified by the US Bureau of Reclamation in a survey of the Blue Nile River between 1956 and 1964. The arguments concerning Ethiopia’s ability to turn off the filling of the reservoir behind the dam is of little consequence as given the current stage of construction, the filling cannot be stopped as it is filling due to the rainy season which has begun and will continue until September. According to Manchester University's Mohammed Basheer, more water is entering the dam site than the volume of water that can physically pass through the two open outlets in the dam wall (60-110 million cubic metres a day).
However, Ethiopia sped up the process by closing three of the four diversion outlets that led to lower levels downstream which disrupted Sudan's pumping stations for irrigation and municipal water supply.
The point of contention appears to be the holder of the rights to the water resource with Egypt’s stating the legal framework was in agreed in 1959 with Sudan for allocation of the Nile waters. This agreement allowed no water for Ethiopia or the other riparian states upstream, being Tanzania, Uganda, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, Burundi, Kenya, Eritrea, and South Sudan.
An argument exists in that Egypt should forgo its perceived historic water rights as defined in the 1929 Anglo-Egyptian Treaty and the 1959 agreement between Egypt and Sudan that only favour those two countries and the Nile River re-designated a regional water course with a resource sharing agreement in a legal framework. The issue has risen due to perceived historic rights and the requirement to modernise and assist in evolving the economies of developing countries. A major stumbling block in resolving (or perhaps helping) the issues may be the involvement of the major powers in involving themselves to influence outcomes.
The US have held back non-humanitarian aid to Ethiopia due to this issue and the problems in the Tigray area.
The Chinese have financial/economic/political interests in Egypt and Ethiopia (Chinese Banks are financing the Dam) and would probably prefer to avoid conflict.
The Russians have just signed a military cooperation agreement with Ethiopia to transform the National Defence Force in knowledge, skill and technology spheres and have been a traditional supplier of military hardware to Ethiopia. 
Given the progress of the Dam’s construction, the capability of Egypt’s armed forces and the logistics involved, major conflict is unlikely.
The Egyptian President under particular pressure from his public.
Only diplomacy and negotiation will resolve this. https://www.water-technology.net/projects/grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-africa/  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53432948 https://apnews.com/article/global-trade-egypt-cairo-moscow-suez-canal-d090a2f5edee60aec9a97369c5235faf
https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20210709-security-council-backs-african-union-mediation-bid-over-disputed-nile-dam

Since 1978 there have been no Egyptian losses in military conflicts besides the Gulf War, the Sinai Insurgency and the Second Libyan Civil War (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Egypt#Arab_Republic_of_Egypt_(1971%E2%80%93present). All of those are completely not comparable to the mild conflict between Egypt and Ethiopia. Both countries even do not have a common border. The only possible options would be that Egypt bombs the Dam (imagine how international isolated Egypt would be after such an aggression) or that Egypt would join forces with another country (nothing has happened here and this would take time). The dam is expected to reach full generating capacity in 2023. There is still a lot of time for diplomacy. I'm pretty sure that all diplomatic options will be tested before Egypt would consider to act. Both the UN Security Council and China could arbitrate between the parties. This is a serious conflict and there is a lot at stake for Egypt. However, they will seek for possibilities to avoid a military conflict. If Ethiopia doesn't make any concessions during the next months, the conflict will heat up. But I cannot imagine that it will come to a military conflict until the end of the year. So I give it 1% probability.

China, China, China.  No shots fired this year.  China will ensure Egypt's compliance with the New World Order by continuing to give belly rubs along the Suez Canal.  Plus, there will be a nice little electricity deal and some promises of access to water.  As a member of the UN Security Council, China has expressed the desire for continued dialogue which ensures peaceful resolution.
